## Problem Set 2

**Compute the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix A.  You'll need to show your work.  You'll need to write out the characteristic polynomial and show your solution.***

\[ A=\begin{bmatrix}
  1 & 2 & 3 \\
  0 & 4 & 5 \\
  0 & 0 & 6 
  \end{bmatrix}
\]

Solve

\[ det \Bigg(\begin{bmatrix}
  1 & 2 & 3 \\
  0 & 4 & 5 \\
  0 & 0 & 6 
  \end{bmatrix} - 
  \begin{bmatrix}
  \lambda & 0 & 0 \\
  0 & \lambda & 0 \\
  0 & 0 & \lambda
  \end{bmatrix} \Bigg) = 0
\]

Simplified to 

\[ det \Bigg(\begin{bmatrix}
  1 - \lambda & 2 & 3 \\
  0 & 4 - \lambda & 5 \\
  0 & 0 & 6 - \lambda 
  \end{bmatrix}  \Bigg) = 0
\]

The determinant of an upper triangular matrix is the product of the diagonal therefore

$(1 - \lambda)(4 - \lambda)(6 - \lambda) = 0$

$(\lambda^2 -5\lambda + 4)(6-\lambda) = 0$

$6\lambda^2 - 30\lambda + 24 - \lambda^3 + 5\lambda^2 -4\lambda = 0$

Simplified to 

$-\lambda^3 + 11\lambda^2 - 34\lambda + 24 = 0$

This is the characteristic polynomial.  Which factorizes to

$-(\lambda-6)(\lambda-4)(\lambda-1) = 0$

So the eigenvalues are $\lambda_1 = 6$, $\lambda_2 = 4$ and $\lambda_3 = 1$  

Substituting $\lambda_1$ into $(A-\lambda I)v = 0$

\[ \Bigg(\begin{bmatrix}
  1 & 2 & 3 \\
  0 & 4 & 5 \\
  0 & 0 & 6 
  \end{bmatrix} - 
  \begin{bmatrix}
  6 & 0 & 0 \\
  0 & 6 & 0 \\
  0 & 0 & 6
  \end{bmatrix} \Bigg)
  \begin{bmatrix}
  v_1\\
  v_2\\
  v_3
  \end{bmatrix}
  = 0
\] or

\[ \begin{bmatrix}
  -5 & 2 & 3 \\
  0 & -2 & 5 \\
  0 & 0 & 0 
  \end{bmatrix}  
  \begin{bmatrix}
  v_1\\
  v_2\\
  v_3
  \end{bmatrix}= 0
\]

Adding row 2 to row 1

\[ \begin{bmatrix}
  -5 & 0 & 8 \\
  0 & -2 & 5 \\
  0 & 0 & 0 
  \end{bmatrix}  
  \begin{bmatrix}
  v_1\\
  v_2\\
  v_3
  \end{bmatrix}= 0
\]

Therefore
$-5v_1 + 8v_3 =0$ and $-2v_2 + 5v_3=0$  Solving for $v_1$

$-5v_1 = -8v_3 \Rightarrow v_1 = \frac{8}{5}v_3$

Solving for $v_2$

$-2v_2 = -5v_3 \Rightarrow v_2=\frac{5}{2}v_3$

So the vector $\begin{bmatrix}
  \frac{8}{5}\\
  \frac{2}{5}\\
  1
  \end{bmatrix}$ is the eigenvector for the eigenvalue 6
